Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation2: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Story: I sat at my desk, the glow of my computer screen illuminating the late hour. My phone buzzed with a message from my granddaughter, her words bubbling with excitement about her new job. She wanted to talk, to share her first impressions and the little victories of her first week. I knew how much it meant to her that I listened, that I was present for these milestones. At the same time, my inbox pinged with a reminder from my project manager—my part of the report was due by midnight, and any delay would hold up the entire team. I could almost feel the weight of my colleagues’ expectations, knowing how much they relied on me to keep things moving. My heart tugged in two directions: the warmth of family, the responsibility of work. I stared at the phone, then at the unfinished report, feeling the pressure build as I wrestled with which role to honor in this moment.
